title: About
text: I am Lindsay McMullen! I am from Morton, IL. I am currently a senior sports media & communications major at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln graduating in December 2025. I have a Bachelor of Science in Secondary Education and History from Bradley University. ​​​​​​​I have a background in high school education, corporate, sports, and hospitality. I can offer a wide variety of skills through my communication, leadership, attention to detail, and organization.

title: Who is the true College Volleyball Power Conference?
text:
The Big Ten has long held the reputation as the dominant women’s volleyball conference, but that status is now being actively debated. The SEC has become a strong contender, adding No. 3 Texas to an existing powerhouse, No. 2 Kentucky, leading some fans to believe the SEC deserves the title. The Pac-12 is often overlooked, which arguably should have been considered the power conference all along due to its record for the most national championships. In recent years, the conversation has centered around the Big Ten, SEC, and ACC, thanks to their dominant seasons over the past five years. As college volleyball continues to rise in popularity, regular season and national championship viewership is seeing a significant increase.
So who is actually the power conference and does it depend on the season?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(ggbump)

nc <- read_csv("TotalNationalChampionships.csv")
pc <- read_csv("VolleyballData.csv")
views <- read_csv("Views.csv")

conf <- pc |> 
  group_by(conference) |> 
  summarize(
    opponent_total_attacks = mean(opponent_hit_pct),
    total_attacks = mean(hit_pct)
  ) 

big12 <- pc |> filter(conference == "Big 12")
acc <- pc |> filter(conference == "ACC")

bar1 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=pc, aes(x=reorder(conference, hit_pct), weight=hit_pct), fill="#000000") + 
  geom_bar(data=acc, aes(x=reorder(conference, hit_pct), weight=hit_pct), fill="#013CA6") + 
  coord_flip() + 
  labs( 
    x="", 
    y="Average Hitting Percentage"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar2 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=pc, aes(x=reorder(conference, opponent_hit_pct), weight=opponent_hit_pct), fill="#000000") + 
  geom_bar(data=big12, aes(x=reorder(conference, opponent_hit_pct), weight=opponent_hit_pct), fill="#C41230") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs( 
    x="", 
    y="Average Opponent Hitting Percentage"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar1 + bar2 + 
  plot_annotation( 
    title = "Which conference leads in hitting and opponent percentage?",
    subtitle = "The conference average hitting percentage and opponent hitting percentage over the past 5 years.",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By Lindsay McMullen "
  )  & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









The main statistics that viewers and announcers look at when it comes to determining a conference’s dominance is hitting percentage and opponent hitting percentage. The ACC has had the highest hitting percentage with teams like Pitt, Louisville and new addition Stanford leading the conference. The Big 12 over the past years has had the best opponent hitting percentage, the lower the number the better.


Code
movers <- c("Oklahoma", "Texas", "UCLA", "Southern California", "Oregon", "Washington", "Stanford", "Arizona", "Arizona State", "Colorado", "California")

movingteams <- pc |> filter(team %in% movers)

ggplot() + 
  geom_bump(data=movingteams, aes(x=season, y=team, color=conference)) + 
  geom_point(data=movingteams, aes(x=season, y=team, color=conference), size = 2) + 
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "#013CA6", #ACC 
    "#C41230", #Big 12 
    "#0088CE", #Big Ten 
    "#092346", #Pac-12
    "#FBCE28" # SEC 
    )) + 
  labs(
    title="Power 5 realignment shifts everything", 
    subtitle="The power 5 has seen a shift in conference alignment and removal of the Pac-12. ", 
    y= "", 
    x = "Season",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By Lindsay McMullen", 
    color="Conference") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Over the past five years, college volleyball’s Power 5 structure has realigned into the Power 4, significantly altering the competitive balance. The historic Pac-12 has broken up, dispersing programs like Stanford, UCLA, USC, Oregon and Washington. The ACC has added Stanford and California. The Big Ten added four new Top 25 contenders. The SEC gained a competitive edge with additions like Oklahoma and Texas, with Kentucky leading the conference. The Big 12 has also seen its ranks boosted, notably with the addition of Top 25-ranked Colorado.


Code
Big10 <- nc |> 
  filter(
    Conference == "Big 10"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nc, aes(x=reorder(Conference, Total), weight= Total) , fill = "black") + 
  geom_bar(data=Big10, aes(x=reorder(Conference, Total), weight= Total), fill = "#0088CE") +
  labs(
    title="Tracking which conference claims the most National Titles ", 
    subtitle="The Pac-12 leads the Power 5 conferences with the most national championships", 
    y= "", 
    x = "Conference",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By Lindsay McMullen", 
    color="Conference") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The ACC has had teams in the national championship and final four every year, but they have yet to win a title. The Pac-12 leads the national title race with 17 and Stanford leading the conference. The Big 12 is 2nd or currently leads the national championship race with 15. The Big 10 has 13 national titles.
What conference will win the next one?


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = views,
    aes(
      x = reorder(Season, Conference),
      weight = Viewership,
      fill = Conference
    ),
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c(
    "Big 10" = "#0088CE",
    "SEC" = "#FBCE28",
    "Pac-12" = "#092346",
    "Big 12" = "#C41230",
    "ACC" = "#013CA6"
  )) +
  coord_flip() + 
labs(
    title="National Championship viewership rises and falls over the years", 
    subtitle="There has been an increase in viewership when over the past years in national championship games", 
    y= "Viewers (Millions)", 
    x = "Season",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By Lindsay McMullen", 
    color="Conference") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Volleyball has seen an increase of on air coverage. National Championships are now being viewed by millions of people. The highest viewed national championship was Nebraska vs Texas in 2023, with Texas winning. The lowest viewed national championship over the past 10 year was 2019: Stanford vs Wisconsin, with Stanford winning. There was a drop in viewership last year with Penn State and Louisville match, even though it was a historical game with the first ever female coach winning.
Will this years national championship viewership increase or stay the same?
